awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Design and Provisioning for Inter-Datacenter Multigranular Flexible Optical Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
There is an ever-increasing demand for cloud computing services, and large-scale datacenters are constantly evolving to meet this demand. As the need for data and data analytics grows, providers are turning to geo-distributed datacenters to provide customers very low latency access to information and computational capability. This results in high capacity, highly-varying inter-datacenter network traffic that must be reliably and cost-effectively accommodated by fiber optic networks.  Recent advances in agile and flexible optical networking have made Flexible Optical Networks (FONs) a promising candidate for meeting these dynamic and heterogeneous connection demands. The goal of this project is to develop network design and provisioning strategies for inter-datacenter FONs that can support a wide range of data traffic flow. To address the continued exponential growth in network capacity, the project includes consideration of a novel, flexible, cost-effective optical technology,  which introduces a way of bundling large traffic demands together as they get routed through the network.  The results of the project will inject leading-edge research into education, and enable more efficient and cost-effective distribution of information between datacenters.

The research project addresses challenging problems in the design and operation of multigranular flexible optical networks. The challenges demand the development of new strategies to maximize the utilization of precious network resources. Novel algorithms for network design and resource provisioning will be developed, and will be accompanied by sophisticated mathematical models and bound analysis for performance quantification. The specific research objectives of this project are to: 
1. Explore the multigranular FONs design space and evaluate performance and complexity trade-offs, balancing performance against complexity or cost.
2. Design algorithms for provisioning bandwidth requests in multigranular FONs.
3. Design scalable and flexible algorithms on provisioning virtual network (VN) requests by jointly allocating compute and communication resources in inter-datacenter networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There is an ever-increasing demand for cloud computing services, and large-scale datacenters are constantly evolving to meet this demand. As the scale of the data continues to increase and latencies become more and more important, providers are turning to geo-distributed datacenters to serve customers at the most proximal datacenter location. Even though intra-datacenter traffic is still dominant, inter- datacenter traffic is growing at a faster rate due to factors such as VM migration, data replication, and data relocation following disasters. The size of data that can be processed in a reasonable amount of time is not only determined by the available processing capability but also by the bandwidth and latency of the interconnecting network. These new requirements pose a serious challenge on network operators who have to come up with a flexible and reliable solution, while considering the operational benefits that can potentially result.

 

Recent advances in agile and flexible optical networking have made Flexible/Elastic Optical Networks (FONs/EONs) a promising candidate for meeting the dynamic and heterogeneous connection demands between datacenters. FONs enable efficient utilization of the optical fiber's bandwidth in an elastic manner by matching customers’ bandwidth demands to fiber bandwidth allocation. An array of FON-based bandwidth-variable transponders and bandwidth-variable switches have been developed for use in FON transport systems. Nevertheless, as networks scale in capacity, fine-grained switching of slots becomes prohibitively expensive; a flexible wavebanding optical crossconnect (OXC) has been recently proposed to offset the large increase in cost. In a multigranular FON, a mix of conventional OXCs and banding OXCs try to achieve a balance between cost and performance. The goal of this project is to (a) explore the network design space and evaluate performance-complexity trade-offs, (b) design algorithms for provisioning bandwidth requests in multigranular FONs, and (c) design scalable and flexible algorithms for jointly allocating compute and communication resources in inter-datacenter networks.

 

The project successfully developed a suite of new algorithms that significantly outperformed those in the literature. The project also successfully demonstrated the use of machine learning in further improving the performance of many previous resource allocation algorithms in EONs. The grant funds were used to train two PhD students at GWU who graduated recently.
